source: A boolean indicating whether the client is confidential or public.
A boolean indicating whether the client uses @pkce (e.g., a native client or SPA)
A boolean indicating whether the token is available.
A unique name for this scope. It must only contain lowercase letters, numbers, underscores, and colons.
Allow to access the administration form to configure Access Token entities.
Allow to manage the OAuth2 scopes.
Allows accessing to extended information about the token and the access it grants under /oauth/debug.
An entity field containing a oauth2_scope reference.
An external client application is requesting access to your data in this site. Please log in first to authorize the operation.
An umbrella scope groups multiple scopes.
Any keys already present in this directory will be deleted.
Are you sure you want to delete entity %name?
Check the Simple OAuth guide for OpenID Connect to learn how to customize the user claims for OpenID Connect.
Claims are defined and managed in the service container. They are only listed here for reference. Please see the documentation above for more information.
Configure the Simple OAuth settings and manage entities.
Disable OpenID Connect if you have a conflicting custom or contributed implementation of OpenID Connect in your site.
Display the label of the referenced OAuth2 scopes.
Enable the scope for specific grant types and optionally give a specific scope description per grant type.
Enabling a grant type is required.
Enabling the PHP OpenSSL Extension will permit you generate the keys from this form.
Field pkce installed for the consumer entity.
Here you can select scopes that would be the default scopes when authorizing.
If a client requests the parent scope it also has any children scopes.
Map scope to a single permission or role.
Reference the scope to a permission; this leverages the resource access.
The %field file at the specified location is not readable.
The ID of the Access Token entity.
The URI this client will redirect to when needed.
The UUID of the Access Token entity.
The absolute URIs to validate against.
The active scope provider. The dynamic scope provider makes use of config entity; which makes it possible to manage the scopes via the UI.
The consumer client for this Access Token.
The number of expired token to delete per batch during cron cron.
The number of seconds that the access token will be valid.
The number of seconds that the refresh token will be valid.
The path to the private key file.
The path to the public key file.
The scope configuration has been saved.
The scopes for this Access Token.
The secret key of this client (hashed).
The time that the entity was created.
The time that the entity was last edited.
target: La date à laquelle l'entité a été modifiée pour la dernière fois.

source: The time when the token expires.
The user ID of the user this access token is authenticating.
This is the directory where the public and private keys will be stored after generation. This SHOULD be located outside of your webroot to avoid making them public unintentionally.
This will cause the authorization form to be skipped.
Use this field to create a hash of the secret key. This module will never store your consumer key, only a hash of it.
When enabled, if previous authorization request with the same scopes got approved, authorization will be automatically accepted.
When no specific user is authenticated Drupal will use this user as the author of all the actions made.
